body.stage: [The accused not present] --- Upon commencing at 9.34 a.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Good morning to everyone in and around this courtroom. Madam Registrar, would you please call the case.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Good morning, Your Honours. This is the case IT-09-92-T, The Prosecutor versus Ratko Mladic.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Registrar. The Chamber establishes that Mr. Mladic is not present in the courtroom. The Chamber was informed that Mr. Mladic refused to enter voluntarily the courtroom, after he insisted on his blood pressure to be taken by a nurse or a doctor instead of by security. If the accused does not wish to enter the courtroom, then the Chamber understands this as a waiver of his right to be present and will not force him into the courtroom. This is the information the Chamber received, Mr. Lukic, but perhaps you'd like to make any submission on that matter.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Your Honour, I'm not an expert, so I don't know what the health status of Mr. Mladic is this morning, and if he refuses to come in without having his blood pressure measured, I understand that he has necessity to do so, and also he informed us that he didn't -- didn't give a waiver for this proceeding to continue without him, and he instructed us just to inform you that we are not allowed to be present in this courtroom without him too.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Well, whether you're allowed or not you may have a duty to be present, but let's not discuss that at this moment. You say you are not an expert so you do not know about the health status --

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: -- and if he refuses to come in without having his blood pressure measure. There's an offer to measure his blood pressure by those qualified to do so and that is security under the present circumstances. And let me inform you of the following, Mr. Lukic. The Chamber has been informed, but we'll ask for a detailed report, if necessary, that Mr. Mladic has made it a routine to ask his blood pressure to be measured and that, in view of his condition, that nothing beyond what is normal for him was ever established during all those days where he insisted, without a medical reason, that his blood pressure should be measured. The Registry has decided that the security is trained and qualified to measure the blood pressure, and in view of the past, that nothing beyond the normal was ever established, the Registry has asked security to measure the blood pressure, and if anything beyond the normal would be established, that further action would be taken. So your presentation that Mr. Mladic refuses to come into court without having his blood pressure measured, in the present circumstances means that he refuses to have his blood pressure measured by persons qualified to do so after a longer history of blood pressure being measured as a routine matter -- as a routine matter where never a medical reason apparently existed. That is the present situation. If you would like to make further submissions. Whether Mr. Mladic waives his right or not, if he does not expressly waive it, then, of course, the Chamber has to consider, whether, by his behaviour, Mr. Mladic implicitly waives his right to follow the proceedings. That's as matters stand, as far as the Chamber is concerned at this moment.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: If I may, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, please.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: With all due respect, I have to differ. Every time the blood pressure is measured, it is out of the limits Mr. Mladic is supposed to have it. He is -- he should not have -- he shall not have blood pressure higher than 146 because of three strokes he suffered previously. Every time it was higher. It was even 190 sometimes. And for him, and he would even shortly lose his conscious at those moments, it's a very dangerous situation for a man of his health. So we had a situations here when he to be brought out, and in those situations, his condition was very critical, I have to inform you. I don't know what kind of information Your Honours have, but I have to tell you this.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The Chamber was informed that what was measured before he entered court was always communicated with the medical staff of the UNDU and never caused any reason to specifically further examine the accused or to raise any alarm. If you think that there's something wrong with that, then you should have taken action so that the accused, you should make a submission to the Registry explaining why you think that further medical examinations would be needed. I do understand, but, again, we should wait for a more -- for a broader report by the Registry, I do understand that the blood pressure of Mr. Mladic is somewhat elevated and that is established in the past, and that this is monitored quite precisely. Any further submissions? Yes, before I give an opportunity to Mr. Groome.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Me first or Mr. Groome first?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Well, let's first hear Mr. Groome and then. Please proceed, Mr. Groome.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: Your Honour, two points. If the Chamber may have already established whether Mr. Mladic has been informed that the security are properly trained to do this so that it's not a misunderstanding. If he has not been -- if it's not been established that he's been informed, perhaps Mr. Lukic should be directed to inform him of that. And secondly, Your Honour, if it's not the practice to record the blood pressure that security is taking, which I imagine it probably is, but if it's not, I would ask the Chamber to consider directing the security to record the blood pressure when they do that so that it would be available for review by the Chamber if necessary.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Just in brief response, the Chamber has understood that the Registry would, as being responsible for the medical care of our detained accused, that the Registry would have communicated with Mr. Mladic about the qualifications and the training of security for taking blood pressure. That's one. Second, I do understand that whatever was measured over the last weeks, and I do understand that this was supposed to be continued, that, always, any measurement, would be relayed to the medical staff of the United Nations Detention Unit. Mr. Lukic, any further submissions?

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: I just want to tell you that we -- I was translating at that moment, but I don't know how artfully I did it, but I did communicate to Mr. Mladic that the guards are telling me that they are trained enough to do blood pressure measuring but if there is anything else they cannot help, and I cannot vouch for them that they can assess if there is anything else. They just told me that they can measure the blood pressure. So that's what I translated to Mr. Mladic, and I translated to them everything he told me, and we tried to persuade him to accept a guards, but he said they are not trained well enough to know if I am sick or not and he refused it. So that was the situation.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The Chamber was informed that Mr. Mladic insisted as a routine matter on blood pressure measurement and is not informed about any further complaint. The Chamber also has in the back of its mind that, in the past when there were complaints and when very serious attention was paid to it, that at least at those instances nothing could be established that was of such a level that it should worry us more as what we knew already on the basis of the general condition known to us by medical reports of Mr. Mladic.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: I don't know how often his blood pressure is measured but I think that it should be a routine measurement taken.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Okay. Then you should have asked for it. Until now, Mr. Mladic insisted on it to be measured every day. The results were always relayed to the United Nations Detention Unit medical staff and no one refused to measure his blood pressure. No other complaints were uttered, as far as I am aware of. I intend to close this discussion, and I'd like to consult with my colleagues.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, the Chamber reached the following conclusions. On the basis of the submissions made, until now, the Chamber cannot establish that there's any medical reason that Mr. Mladic is unable to attend court. That's one. Second, please convey to Mr. Mladic that he has an opportunity to attend court after I've -- we'll make a short break. And that if he doesn't take that opportunity, that the Chamber will continue to hear the case, and that if Mr. Mladic refuses to enter court, that he can follow the proceedings from elsewhere, but we're not going to interrupt the testimony of the next witness for Mr. Mladic at a later stage to enter. So if he decides not to enter the courtroom, then he'll -- he will only be allowed to enter the courtroom again once we start with the testimony of the next witness. The Chamber considers that it's the duty of the Defence, at least to be present in court, I'm not giving you any instructions as what to do or what not to do. Whatever you decide, the Chamber will continue to hear the case and would consider it an obligation. But, again, we're not hear at this moment to judge upon your obligations, but we consider it the obligation of the Defence to be present in court to look after the interests of the accused in the way they consider proper. Therefore, we'll take a break of two minutes. You'll have an opportunity to inform Mr. Mladic about this all, and then we're back in court and we'll continue either in the presence of Mr. Mladic or in his absence. We take a break. --- Break taken at 9.50 a.m.

body.stage: [The accused entered court] --- On resuming at 10.00 a.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The Chamber establishes that Mr. Mladic has entered the courtroom. Is the Prosecution ready to call its next witness?

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour. Though there are two quick preliminary matters.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Before the witness can be called.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please raise them.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: First, Your Honours, in your oral ruling on the Rule 92 ter motion for Witness RM083, the Chamber directed at transcript page 2001 that we provide information regarding RM083's proffer of testimony. Specifically, you asked that we inform the Chamber first who authored the proffer of testimony and, second, when and where the interview with the witness which forms the basis for the proffer was conducted. According to Prosecution records, the proffer was drafted by an OTP staff member, named Mazhar Inayat, on the basis of an interview conducted by OTP staff with the witness on May 1998 in the witness's country of residence as of that time. The proffer was taken by an OTP investigator, like any other witness statement. The investigator called it a proffer of testimony because the witness did not review and sign the statement at the time it was taken. Two years later, the witness did review the information recorded during that interview and incorporated it by reference into his formal statement signed on 20 September 2000. And if Your Honours have other questions [Overlapping speakers]

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Traldi, when you said the proffer was drafted by an OTP staff member, and then you gave his name, on the basis of an interview conducted by OTP staff with the witness, may I understand this that the drafter of the proffer was present during the interview?

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: The same investigator, I'm told, made the -- made notes during the course of the interview with the witness, and on the basis of those, the proffer was drafted.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: So the answer is yes, he was present during the interview. Yes. Thank you for that.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: So where was it drafted?

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: I withdraw my question.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, that was the first preliminary matter. Thank you for updating the Chamber. Mr. Traldi, next.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: The other preliminary matter, Your Honours, is the adjudicated facts. And I want to reiterate here from our filing that Mr. Taci's evidence does overlap with adjudicated facts particularly regarding Keraterm camp and the room massacre; facts 1027 to 1054. We have reviewed Mr. Taci's Rule 92 ter material and made appropriate redactions. We have also redacted a paragraph of his proffer of testimony pursuant to a Defence request in its response to our 92 ter motion for this witness. That is paragraph 40 of the proffer.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And you have uploaded the new versions, may I take it?

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour, we have.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. And you have communicated with the Defence the new versions. Mr. Stojanovic.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: We have received that document, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Traldi for this information. These are the two issues you would like to raise?

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour. That's correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Now, Mr. Lukic, the Chamber was informed there was a preliminary matter. Now I do not know whether that was the matter we discussed earlier or whether that's an other matter?

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Another matter, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Another matter.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Just a short one.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, please.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: We would kindly ask Your Honours to empower our colleague Dan Ivetic to cross-examine Witness RM039 who is coming tomorrow.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We will consider it during the first break and let you know.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Then could the witness be escorted into the courtroom. Mr. Traldi, no protective measures? 92 ter.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: That's correct, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Good morning, Witness, Mr. Taci, I take it. Mr. Taci, before you give evidence, the Rules require that you make a solemn declaration. The text is now handed out to you by the usher. May I invite you to make that solemn declaration.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: I solemnly declare that I will speak the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you. Please be seated, Mr. Taci.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Taci, you'll be first examined by Mr. Traldi. Mr. Traldi is counsel for the Prosecution, and you'll find him on your right. Please proceed, Mr. Traldi.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, can I ask you first to please state your full name for the record.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Safet Taci.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And can you tell us where you were born?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I was born in Kozarac.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what municipality is that in?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The municipality of Prijedor.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What's your ethnicity, sir?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I'm a Muslim.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, Mr. Taci, do you remember providing a statement to the ICTY on 20 September 2000?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Your Honours, I'd ask the Court Officer to please display 65 ter 28361 on our screens. It's the statement signed by the witness on 20 September 2000.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, now that the document is on the screen before you, I'd ask that you view the first page here and look at the signature in the bottom right-hand corner of the English version on the right of your screen, and I'd ask you to indicate to the Trial Chamber whether you recognise that signature.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that's my signature.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: I'd ask that we turn to the last page now.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, again, I'd ask you if you recognise the signature on that page.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And on the first page of this statement -- oh. Sorry. And whose signature is that, sir?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It's my signature.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And on the first page of this statement, it says that in preparing it you reviewed a document entitled "proffer of testimony of Witness Safet Taci."

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: I'd ask the Court Officer to now display 65 ter 28360 on our screens.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, is this the document you reviewed entitled your proffer of testimony?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did this document called a proffer record information you provided to the Office of the Prosecutor during an interview in 1998?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And have you had an opportunity to read and review your statement and your proffer in preparation for your appearance here today?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And if I were to ask you today, sir, questions about the material addressed in these documents, would you provide the same information in substance?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I think so.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now that you have taken the solemn declaration, do you affirm that you provided the information in the your statement and your proffer of testimony in accordance with the truth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: And, Your Honours, the Prosecution tenders 65 ter 28360 and 28361 into evidence pursuant to Rule 92 ter as public exhibits.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Traldi. First, 28360, the proffer of testimony. Mr. Stojanovic, after the explanation by the Prosecution, any further objections?

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: No, Your Honours. We don't have any objections. We have both statements.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Madam Registrar, this proffer of testimony under the number I just mentioned, which is now redacted, paragraph 40 being taken out, would receive number?

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 28360 becomes Exhibit P158, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: P158 is admitted into evidence. Then the witness statement of Mr. Taci September 2000.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 28361 becomes Exhibit P159, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And is admitted into evidence. Please proceed, Mr. Traldi.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour. With the Chamber's permission now that the requirements of Rule 92 ter have been satisfied, I will briefly summarise RM083's written evidence for the record.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please do so.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Safet Taci was born and raised in Prijedor municipality. In the beginning of 1992 he was working in Zagreb while his wife and two children were living in Prijedor. Mr. Taci returned home to take his wife and children away due to rising tensions in the area. When he reunited with his family in their predominantly village of Hrnici, Mr. Taci heard announcements on the radio directing non-Serbs to surrender and turn over power to the Serbs. Soon thereafter, tanks arrived in his village and a soldier told people that they should surrender or they would be killed. On a Saturday afternoon in the late spring of 1992, Hrnici and other nearby villages were attacked. Mr. Taci fled to Sivci. On 14 and 15 June 1992, Serb forces rounded up non-Serb men in Sivci. Mr. Taci was put on a bus with men who had been beaten and bloodied and they were taken to Keraterm. On the way, he and other men were beaten and threatened by Serb soldiers, and Mr. Taci saw dead bodies and destroyed homes. When Mr. Taci arrived at Keraterm, he was put in room with 500 other men, some of whom had been severely beaten. One day, 180 to 200 people, mostly from Hambarine, were squeezed into room saw at Keraterm. Mr. Taci had saw a spot light pointed at the room and a machine-gun aimed at the door. Eventually the door opened, people ran out, and the machine-gun began firing. The next morning, Mr. Taci and other prisoners were ordered to load the bodies of dead and wounded people onto a truck together. He became physically ill. Then Mr. Taci was taken to Trnopolje. He left Trnopolje around 21 August 1992 on a bus in a convoy bound for Travnik. During the trip, men were ordered off the bus, but Mr. Taci remained aboard. His brother-in-law got off. Before the bus drove away, Mr. Taci could see that men had been lined up two by two. He never saw his brother-in-law again. And that concludes the summary of this witness's written evidence, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Traldi. If you have any further questions, please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: I do, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Taci, now that I have summarised your written evidence, I'm going to ask several questions to clarify or expand upon that evidence. First, sir, can you tell us what the atmosphere was like in your area of Prijedor when you arrived in April 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The atmosphere was getting increasingly tense, more and more dramatic. The traffic between Prijedor, Banja Luka, and Trnopolje had been obstructed. Schools had stopped working. Children stopped going to schools. The telephones weren't working. You couldn't contact anyone anymore. The water supply was cut off. The lighting, the town lights were cut off. This all led to psychological tension. People didn't know what to expect and didn't know what might happen. People from the surrounding villages in the Kozarac area in the direction of Marakovac, for example, or people from other areas, from Jakopci all gathered in one place in the village of Sivci and that's where the buses collected them. They stopped there, some came, others left, but the tension grew from day to day because there was also a shortage of food. There was no electricity. People were losing patience, and given the uncertainty of the situation it was tense. The buses that arrived with Serbian soldiers who had gathered these people put them on the buses and took them to various places, to camps, to camps such as Omarska and Keraterm that are well-known. Some stayed in Trnopolje, others were taken away in an unknown direction, others lingered in houses that weren't in those places. I stayed with a relative of mine. On the following day, they cleared the village of men, of adults, and they took them away to these camps again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you say in your proffer of testimony, now Exhibit P158, that you had gone back to Prijedor to take your family out. Did you ever wind up bringing them out of Prijedor?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I tried to do this on several occasions. I tried to pay for it. I did everything so that we could leave together. My wife and my children and myself. But the noose was tightening. It was becoming more and more expensive. The tickets cost up to 2.000 German marks to go to Croatia or to free territory. That was per person, and this was impossible for -- for us to pay. I didn't have such money. I was the only one working. My wife and children stayed at home. We lived from selling farm produce as well, so it wasn't possible to pay, and they could not leave, which is why we stayed there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, you say in your proffer, now Exhibit P158, that the forces attacking Hrnici seemed to be targeting the local mosque. Can you tell us how you knew they were targeting the mosque?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, I could observe this when I saw the shelling from the surrounding hills, from Kozara. The shells fell around the mosque, on the whole, and a friend of mine had a house 2- or 300 metres away. Someone was probably trying to direct the shells because the shell -- the shells were falling nearer and nearer the mosque and finally the mosque was hit by one of the shells.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: I'd ask that the Court Officer call up 65 ter 10891 at this time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, I'm now going to ask you a few questions about your time in Keraterm camp. First, sir, do you recognise the building in this picture?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And can you tell the Trial Chamber what that building is?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As far as I know, this was a warehouse for ceramic tiles. You have open rooms there and concrete on the floor. It's just a warehouse. Later it was transformed and it became the Keraterm camp.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And to the best of your knowledge, sir, does this picture fairly and accurately depict the warehouse at the Keraterm camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Yes, it does.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Your Honours, I request that 65 ter 10891 be admitted into evidence as a public exhibit.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Madam Registrar.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 10891 becomes Exhibit P160, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: P160 is admitted into evidence.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, your proffer of testimony describes the conditions in room 2 at Keraterm where it says you were detained along with 500 other people. Could you describe those people for the Trial Chamber, including their approximate ages, genders, and ethnicity.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When I had just arrived in the Keraterm camp, the Serbian soldiers first ordered us to lie down on the concrete, on the asphalt that was very hot. It was insufferable, intolerable. We had to lie down on our stomachs and put our hands behind our backs and turn our heads to the side, and we remained lying on that hot concrete or asphalt, whatever it was. It was intolerable. People tried not to have direct contact with the asphalt, by the Serbian soldiers noticed that, and one came and hit someone in the head, kicked him in the head and told him to lie down. Some tried to turn around on the other side. I myself tried to do that. But they knew which side you were lying on, but we tried to turn to the other side to get a bit of air. Later, they ordered us after a certain period of time to get up, to put all our personal belongings in a box - everything we had in our pockets was to be put in a box - and then they took two people to one room, three to another, five to another room. I went to room number 2 where the situation was terrible. It was very hot. Some people had been beaten inside, and they were being -- they were -- they were groaning because it hurt. We had give them some room for them to lie down there because we were lined up next to each other. It was a small room, 10 by 12 metres, perhaps, and it's difficult for 500 men, 500 people to fit in such a room. Some would leave, others would arrive. There was some people who couldn't sit down, they had to remain lying down and they took up even more space. When they lied down, people were afraid. They had been beaten. They didn't know anything about their families' fate. They didn't know where they were or how they were. As time passed, the situation grew worse. There was no hygiene, nothing. We'd been confined there. It was summer. I only had a T-shirt like this one on me. I tried to take it off. On one occasion it fell to pieces. They trampled on us. They would tread on our stomachs, on our head. We couldn't drive them away because we'd been put in such a room, and there was tin on the sides and the room became very heated. And they threw in a plastic barrel to the left of the entrance on one occasion. They closed the door. We didn't have any air --

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, I'm sorry to interrupt. But if I could ask you, you say there were 500 other men in the room. Can you just tell us maybe anything those men might have had in common - their nationality, their approximate ages - to help us identify the people who were in the room with you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were not of the same ethnicity or of the same age. When we were moved to Trnopolje, I think the age range was from 16 to 70, in my estimate. There were also Croats there that I knew personally from Trnopolje who were there.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Traldi, there may be some confusion. I think your question was about Keraterm. However, the answer in the last part was about Trnopolje. What Mr. Traldi would like to know, Mr. Taci, I think is, if you say not all the people in Keraterm, the 500 people, were of the same ethnicity, does that mean that all ethnicities were represented among the 500?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Not all. As I said, it was just Muslims who were there and some Croats whom I knew. Non-Serb population. The non-Serb population, 100 per cent.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Were they men or women?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Men.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Age? Could you tell us something about their age, even if there was a range, what that range approximately was?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: From 16 to 70, even older than that. That is my estimate of the age range.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Traldi, please proceed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, you say you were also in Trnopolje. When you were detained there, were the other prisoners of the same ethnicities that were held at Keraterm? That is to say, Muslims and Croats.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were the oldest and youngest prisoners in Trnopolje about the same age, 16 and 70, as the oldest and youngest prisoners you identified in Keraterm?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they were there, or they were later transferred to Trnopolje from Keraterm.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And the oldest and youngest prisoners in the camp, did they remain there the whole time you were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Which camp are you thinking of, sir?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At this point I'm asking about Trnopolje, sir.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they were. I'm sorry, could you repeat the question again, please.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yes. In Trnopolje, the oldest and youngest prisoners who were in the camp with you, did they remain in the camp from when you got there till when you departed, the entire time you were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they did.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: And, Your Honours, I'll limit my examination regarding the conditions in room and in Trnopolje in reliance upon the adjudicated facts.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The same observation as I made earlier, that, of course, you draw the lines. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: I appreciate that, Your Honour. I'd ask the Court Officer now bring 65 ter 05987 to our screens. This is a report from the 1st Krajina Corps regarding events on 24 July 1992.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Meanwhile, I'd like to ask one additional question. In Trnopolje, Mr. Taci, were there any women and/or children?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes, there were. Before I arrived, and they brought them in after I arrived. Those who remained in the neighbouring villages. Some were later deported, but some did come later. I did see women and children around.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. And children. That means also children below the age of 16?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you. Please proceed, Mr. Traldi.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, on page of the English and pages and of the B/C/S in e-court, this report says as follows: "The prisoners at the collection centre in Prijedor located in the Keraterm factory attempted a mass escape on the night of the 24th. The attempt was thwarted, and about 50 persons were killed in the process."

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Do we see in the B/C/S version this portion as well?

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: In the B/C/S, Your Honour, it's at the bottom of page in the e-court and continues at the top of page 3. You will see the word "Keraterm" in quotes in the bottom right-hand corner of page 1 and that's the sentence.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. That was not on our screens a minute ago, I think. I mean, we see it in the English ... Could we move to the second -- next page in the B/C/S.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: And it's the very top of this page, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. I now see it. We didn't have the bottom of the previous page earlier on our screen. Have you had an opportunity to read it, Mr. Taci? Perhaps you again read, Mr. Traldi, so that Mr. Taci has the whole of the portion.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, the text says: "The prisoners at the collection centre in Prijedor located in the Keraterm factory attempted a mass escape on the night of the 24th. The attempt was thwarted and about 50 prisoners were killed in the process." That's the end of the quote. Was there a mass escape attempt the night of the room massacre?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The statement is totally incorrect. First of all, it wasn't a collection centre. It was a camp. It was a torture camp. And then it was not 50 people. I think in my estimate it was up 200. Surely people did not try to escape at all. Afterwards, I found out after the mass killing, I spoke with a young man who survived. He said that he had been poisoned and that he fainted. I asked him how did he survive, and he said that the Serbian soldiers lobbed toxins into the room. People were panicking. They felt worse and worse. It was a small room. It was stifling. They ripped their shirts off. They tried to avoid the toxins that were inside or whatever it was there. I'm not sure what it was exactly, but he fainted, and the others forced the doors open so that they could get some air. They were shouting, Kill us, rather, but let us out. And then there were shouts from the Serbian side. They were shouting, Halt. Don't run. But it was all just a trick. People couldn't go out. They were crowding and pushing around the door, and they were greeted by gun-fire once they got to the door.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, finally, sir, in your written evidence, you describe the next morning wounded and dead people being loaded onto a truck together. My question is: Did any of the wounded people who were loaded onto that truck ever come back to Keraterm camp alive?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The following morning, the trucks came, large trailer trucks. They parked so that the rear end was facing room 3. The bodies were strewn all around. They were not gathered into a pile because the people were trying to escape, and then they ordered us to load the bodies. First of all, they asked for volunteers. People didn't dare to come out. Then they made a few people get out and load the bodies onto the trucks. There was still some wounded people there who were helping. They didn't know the number of dead was larger. All of them had to be loaded onto the trucks, and then the trucks left. I never saw the people who were wounded again.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Your Honours, this completes my examination. I would ask that 65 ter 05987 be admitted as a public exhibit. The document was seized from CSB Banja Luka in 1998, and as Your Honours can see from looking at page of the B/C/S original the document is signed, dated, and bears a stamp referring to the 1st Krajina Corps. In my submission, it carries sufficient indicia of authenticity for admission.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: In the absence of any objections, Madam Registrar.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 05987 becomes Exhibit P161, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: P161 is admitted into evidence. Mr. Stojanovic, in view of the -- a bit extraordinary course of proceedings this morning, the Chamber is considering to have only two, and perhaps slightly longer breaks. Are you ready to start your cross-examination which would then go until -- at least the first portion, until 11.00? Mr. Taci, you'll now be cross-examined by Mr. Stojanovic. Mr. Stojanovic is counsel for Mr. Mladic. You'll find him to your left.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Good morning, Mr. Taci.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I am Miodrag Stojanovic and I'm representing, with the rest of the Defence team, Mr. Mladic. I would like to put some questions to you regarding your testimony. I understood that the events in Slovenia and Croatia which preceded the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina happened when you were in Zagreb; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You told the OTP that you were not militarily engaged there.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they ask you to join the military?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, they did not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you decided to go to Bosnia after seeing what was going on there.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not go with the intention of seeing what was going on there, but I went in order to take my wife and children to free territory.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you reached your village in late April 1992; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Would you please tell the Court which route did you take to get to Prijedor?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, I really couldn't tell you. The buses were not taking the main roads or the roads that they used to take before. Mostly it was the direction of Slavonski Brod through Derventa. After that, I wasn't really following which route it was, so I really couldn't say how I got there. In any event, I reached Kozarac from the direction of Banja Luka.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'm asking you this simply because at the time the state border between Bosanski and Slavonski Brod and between this area and Derventa, there was intense fighting between the Croatian and the Serbian armed forces. Did you see that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did see soldiers, of course, but I didn't see any fighting.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And on the road, were you stopped at check-points by the police or the military of either of the warring parties?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, we were.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And nobody prevented you at that time from reaching Prijedor; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. We showed our IDs, our bags were checked, and that was all.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, did you serve in the Yugoslav People's Army?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you please tell us when and where, and if at that time you were a military conscript?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I served in 1983 in the then-Yugoslav People's Army. I served in the Republic of Slovenia in Postojna to be precise.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And I asked you whether at the time - 1991, 1992, early 1992 - you were a military conscript and were on military lists?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I wasn't. Nobody looked for me either. I told you that I worked in Croatia, my company was located in Zagreb, and no one called me up and I was not obliged to respond. I was not a conscript.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you came to Bosnia and Herzegovina, it was not your goal to join any kind of unit or to take part in the fighting?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not in the least. I was not definitely going there to fight for anything. I just went because I wanted to take my family out. I had tried already a couple of times before, but I didn't succeed.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did you tell in any procedure, any state or judicial organ, did you tell them about your reasons why you went there, in 1990 -- did you tell them any different reasons as to why you left?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not. I told them these very same reasons. Go ahead, I can hear you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'm sorry, I'm just pausing. I'm waiting for the translation to finish. That's I'm waiting, so just so that you know. When you came in April 1992, did you have any prior indication of what was going on as far as the security situation was concerned in Prijedor and the surrounding area?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I didn't have any information about that. I saw on TV in Croatia that there was firing and shelling in Sarajevo and that it was spreading to other places. But from what we could hear, it seemed quiet in our area. There was no combat, no arrests, no shooting, and this is why I left in the first place, to try to get my family out.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you arrived Bosnia, or to Prijedor or, rather, Kozarac, did you notice that the political and the security situation was beginning to deteriorate?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you please tell us if you knew that the incident in Kozarac, which caused this deterioration, was prompted by the placing of the flag on the police station in Kozarac?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I heard stories that the Serbian forces wanted to take down these flags, I don't know which flag exactly was there, that they wanted to put up the Serb flag. It was already under Serbian control, and 99 per cent of the Muslim population in Kozarac did not agree with them putting up this flag. I don't know if this is the beginning of everything that happened or not, but I know that they did not want to agree to this change of flag.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did you hear that there was a referendum conducted in Bosnia on the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did hear about that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear that the Serbian people in Bosnia and Herzegovina, as the constitutive people, requested that -- or stated that a referendum could not be conducted without the participation or the will of one of the people?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did hear about that.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, have you ever communicated with the Prosecution? For example, this last question, that the Serbian people thought that the referendum could not be conducted without their participation. Is there any dispute about this? I'm looking at you. I'm also looking at Mr. Groome. Apart from anything else. Just whether that was what the -- what was claimed by the Serbian people.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: Your Honour, I do not believe so, but the Prosecution welcomes an opportunity to meet the Defence to discuss any of these matters, and the Prosecution remains open to agreeing to facts which are beyond reasonable dispute.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, I would encourage you to engage in such discussions. Because what we hear is that the witness heard about all these kind of things. Rather, establish it in a more proper way or agree on that, this is what happened. You may proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour. I will continue. That will only serve as the basis for my next question.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, in view of the guidance that we received just now, after you said that you had heard that the representatives of the Serbian people refused to accept this referendum at the Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovina, I want to ask you: Who did you hear this from, when did you hear it, and exactly what did you hear regarding the position of the Serbian people of Bosnia and Herzegovina?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Actually, I heard it on the Serbian radio in Prijedor that was already under the control of the Serbian forces. They had Prijedor under their control.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. Let me just ask you this: Did you know that there was a police station outpost in Kozarac that was a subdivision of the police station in Prijedor? Were you aware of that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you know that the -- there was a division along ethnic lines among the police in all the police stations in the Prijedor area?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did know about that. When the Serbian forces captured Prijedor, they disarmed their colleagues whom they used to work with. They sent them home or wherever. They were no longer serving in the Serbian army. They were not -- they didn't trust them anymore. And I didn't really know that many people in Kozarac, but I think that also in the local commune in Kozarac it was the same thing: Only Muslim policemen remained.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. And now this question: Are you aware that in the Prijedor municipality area in the settlement of Ljubija, Croatian policemen stayed there and they ran the police department there in Ljubija?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I didn't know that. It was not something that I could have heard. We didn't really have that much information or any reports from Ljubija or from the environs of Prijedor. We were just focussing on our own suffering, if I can put it that way, and what was happening with us, with our wives and children. I didn't hear about that. I'm not informed about that. I didn't know anything about it.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Your Honours, perhaps this is a good moment. I'm about to move to another topic. So perhaps it's a good time to take the break now.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Stojanovic, it is a good moment. Could you tell us how much more time you would need?

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour. In view of the documents and the questions, I expect I will need another 45 minutes. And I also have another request. My colleagues have told me that General Mladic is not feeling well again, and perhaps it would be a good thing for somebody to look at him after all. Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: That is a matter for the Registry. We will take a break, and we'll -- since we will take only two breaks, we'll take a little bit of a longer break. But I will first ask the witness to be escorted out of the courtroom. Mr. Taci, would you please go with the usher. We'll take a break of half an hour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We'll take a break, and we'll resume at 11.30. --- Recess taken at 11.01 a.m. --- On resuming at 11.39 a.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Could the witness be escorted into the courtroom. Mr. Lukic, it's -- the request that Mr. Ivetic cross-examines the witness coming second after this witness is granted.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I also put on the record that the Chamber was informed that Mr. Mladic has been seen by the nurse and that we continue.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Taci, please be seated.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, you may proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Thank you. Could I kindly ask Your Honours for the document 65 ter 1D00111. It's a document we've had occasion to see more than once before. It has not yet been admitted into evidence, and we are looking for an opportunity to tender it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: May I just ask you to look at the left side of your screen with the B/C/S version. This is a document authored by the commander of the Territorial Defence Staff of Bosnia-Herzegovina, Hasan Efendic, dated 29 April 1992. That is after your arrival in Bosnia-Herzegovina. In item 4 we read, among other things: "Accelerate the planning of and commence combat activities in the entire territory of the Republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina and co-ordinate them with the Territorial Defence Staffs of the regions, districts, and the republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina." First of all let me ask you: Have you had occasion to see this document before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Second, I want to ask you: Living in your village, was there any time when you noticed the implementation of this order in terms of organising and commencing combat activities in the area, which is your native area?

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, how is this witness supposed to know that, that is, in effecting this order if he didn't know anything about the order?

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: With all due respect, Your Honour, let me answer. This man was in that area at the time when it was engulfed in serious combat activity which the witness must have noticed, and my question to him is had he noticed any preparation for these activities.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: The question was Mr. Stojanovic, and I'll read it to you: "Second, I want to ask you: Living in your village, was there any time when you noticed the implementation of this order?" That's what you asked. And I'm saying: He is telling you now he has never seen this order before, how would he know that any activity in his village is in compliance or in implementation of this order. How would he know that?

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour. In that case, I will try to get at my point in a different way.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: With all due respect to what you've said already, sir, was there any time while you were living in your village when you saw the preparation and organisation of your villagers for an organised defence?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not see any gatherings or hear any appeals on the part of the Muslim population, as we call it. But I did see such activity on the part of the Serbian army. Because even before the shelling, a tank was placed at the intersection in Kozarac, whereas the people had already been intimidated enough and they did not dare go there. The people felt uncertainty and anxiety and what were we supposed to expect, we, the people in Kozarac and the surrounding area. In the part between us and Croatia everything had already been blocked.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Perhaps needless to say, but the question was about villagers, whereas the document, if you still are referring to the document, is about TO. Now if you say it's all the same, then, of course, we will move on, but at least if you wanted to establish whether what is seen is the -- in the document apart from whether it was the implementation of this decision, but then, please, it would be better to then to use, at least, for factual observations the -- what the document tells us. Let's proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, the next thing I want to ask you is this, and I will call up a document in e-court.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: While we are waiting, let me say that it is a report on the work of the public security station in Prijedor for the past nine months, as you can see on the cover page. And now let us look at page in B/C/S, and page in English. Let's look at the next page, in B/C/S and English. Now, please, look at the second paragraph in this report. It says that the war activities began on 22 May 1992, when Muslim extremists attacked five military conscripts in the village of Hambarine. My question is: Did you ever hear what actually happened there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: First of all, I don't come from Hambarine. It's about 115 kilometres away. I know about the place, as such, but I've never been there. I spent most of my time working in Croatia. Concerning this killing and all these activities, I was not even able to hear anything about it, especially on that day, because we were completely isolated. I told you at the beginning that we did not have any telephone communications or electricity or water. We had to make do as best we could, get water from a well, et cetera.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear what happened in this incident after the event?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard a bit when I was detained in Keraterm when those people were brought in. Something to the effect that they had organised some attacks in Ljubija. I heard that from people who were talking to them from the Serbian side. I heard they were brought there, placed in a separate room, and they ended up the way they ended up, which I already described.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. Look at the next passage in this paragraph. It says the conflict escalated with the attack on the military convoy in Jakupovici village on 24 May 1992. Are [as interpreted]
Jakupovici close to Kozarac and the place where you lived?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know how much the distance matters, but roughly I would say it's 10 to 12 kilometres away from Kozarac and I am still further down on the other side in Hrnici village. But we never went there, nor we had any communication with Jakupovici, nor did I have any information as to what was going on there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After these events, were you informed at any point that there had been a attack against a military convoy?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, I suggest to you that you first try to find out whether the witness has any knowledge about an event before you put documents to him which describe that event. And I would also encourage you to ask the witness mainly about things he observed personally and knows something about. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: I will, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I shall ask you, without calling up any documents, did you have information at any time that the armed formations of Bosnia-Herzegovina attacked the town of Prijedor wherein 17 members of the police force and the Army of the Republika Srpska were killed?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, would -- would a time-frame perhaps possibly assist the witness to answer your question?

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'm asking about an event that happened on the 30th of May, 1992.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This is not the first time that I'm saying this. We had absolutely no information from Prijedor. I did not move anywhere from my village. I did not speak to anyone. I did not communicate with anybody. We had no access to information from the media for me to be able to hear what was going on elsewhere. We were in complete isolation.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. Did you have occasion at any point to meet or hear about a man called Slavko Ecimovic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: During your stay in Keraterm or Trnopolje, did you have occasion to meet or hear about a man called Aziz Aliskovic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This is the first time I hear the name.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Are you aware that after these incidents in Kozarac, an ultimatum was made through Radio Prijedor and other media to civilians to surrender their weapons and for civilians to move elsewhere to stay with families in Prijedor to avoid casualties?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, the last event you talked about was an attack on the town of Prijedor by armed formations of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Now what other incident did you refer to in your question when you said, "...after these incidents in Kozarac," which, apparently, is -- is not an attack on the town of Prijedor. Could you be a bit more precise in your questioning.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After the incidents related to the attack against the column in Jakupovici - I'm talking about the attack also against the soldiers in Hambarine - did you have occasion before the army attacked Kozarac to hear such communication?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not. And I've already said a couple of times, we had no access to media reports. The postal services had not been working for a while already. There were no newspapers. It's only after the tank was placed at the intersection that I heard sirens and people started moving out and seeking safety. Maybe if some families had moved even earlier in order not to find themselves in that encirclement.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I was asked to ask you this: At that time, did you have a military obligation in the sense that you were a conscript who was obligated to report to the police force or an army unit?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Nobody called me up and there was no army. By that time, people were in an encirclement. They were going about in civilian clothing and they had absolutely no chance at defending themselves.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: For those who are not familiar with the testing system of Dutch sirens, I just inform you that on the every first Monday of the month at exactly 12.00, there's a test of the sirens so there's nothing worrying, apart from the testing being done.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: With your leave, Your Honour, could I briefly speak to Mr. Mladic.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Briefly, yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, I earlier suggested that Mr. Mladic takes off his earphones because that explains, most likely, the level of the volume of his voice. But since consultation is done by now, let's proceed. Mr. Stojanovic.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I would just like to clarify the last part of your answer. Bearing in mind the fact that you said that you did your military service in the JNA, my question is as follows: In accordance with the war-time assignment, after you had, in fact, done your military service, did you have a position you were to report to in the case of war, and if that was the case, to which military or war-time unit were you to report to? Is that information that is contained in your military booklet?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As I said, I was a military conscript and I was involved in military training on Manjaca. As to whether I was to report there, you know where Manjaca is located, well, I was never called. Again, I never went up there, and I wouldn't have gone there even if I had been summoned.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So did you have a war-time assignment, since you went to Croatia to do anything there? Were you under the obligation of reporting to any units there? Is there anything you can tell us about that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. No one ever asked me about that. Croatia was already at war. People were walking around town. No one ever asked me whether I was a conscript, whether I should report to anyone if the town or the place was attacked. I never received information of that kind. I never received a summons of any kind.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After the Serbian armed forces entered Kozarac -- where were you, in fact, located when they entered Kozarac?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, I was in my relative's house. In my mother-in-law's house.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: That was the village of Sivci, a few kilometres from Kozarac; isn't that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Correct.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you at any point in time see members of the armed Bosniak forces in the village of Sivci?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: They took you away in the direction of Keraterm in a mini-bus, if I have understood you correctly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, you have.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The man who drove you there didn't allow anyone to stop you, maltreat you, or abuse you; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, he had to stop because we reached a barricade and had to turn back. But he didn't want anyone to get off the mini-bus, although they asked for at least two persons to get out of the mini-bus. But the driver didn't want to let these two people out. He said he'd return them later, but he had to go to Prijedor for an interrogation with them. That's what happened, more or less.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You don't know who that person is, to this very day?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I couldn't know his name. He was wearing civilian trousers and a sort of camouflage shirt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Having arrived in Keraterm, did you at any point in time find out who had organised those facilities to serve as a collection centre or camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I didn't hear about any one person having organised this, but it's quite natural that it was the Serbian forces who were behind its organisation.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: While you were in Keraterm, you were taken away for interrogation?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know the person who interrogated you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I don't.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Would you agree with me if I said that it was an inspector in civilian clothing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. He was in civilian clothing, but as for being an inspector, well, I don't know. Perhaps he just an ordinary citizen, a peasant. I don't know.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The subject of his interrogation, what he interrogated you about was where you lived in Croatia and what you did there; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: He also asked you how it was possible for you to reach Prijedor in April 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, he didn't ask me about that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, by the way, did you go there by bus; and how did you travel between Derventa and Banja Luka in April 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I haven't understood your question.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'll try and rephrase it. I'm interested in part of your trip when you travelled between Derventa, which was under the control of the Croatian armed forces at the time, to Banja Luka, which was under the control of the Serbian forces at the time. How did you travel between those two points?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I said I travelled by bus. But as for the route the bus took, whether it drove down the main road or byroads, I don't know. But in any event, I returned home from the direction of Banja Luka.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: On that occasion, no one forced you to give any kind of statement. What you said, you said of your own free will?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. They asked me whether I had anything in my bag, what do you have in your bag, they asked for my ID, and that was it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you were interrogated by this civilian in Keraterm, did anyone beat you there or did anyone ask you to state something that did not correspond to the truth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, not in the course of the interrogation.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You spent a total of one month in Keraterm, or just over a month in Keraterm; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: During that period of time, were you able to see whether Keraterm was under military or civilian supervision?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think it was under military supervision because they were wearing camouflage uniforms. But, in fact, I didn't know whether the police had perhaps changed their uniforms.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Your conclusion is based on the type of uniforms that the guards were wearing; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I couldn't have concluded that on any other basis.

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Interpreter's correction: Counsel previously asked whether it was under the supervision of the military or of the police.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I will ask you about certain questions that you mentioned in your statement. Do you remember that you mentioned someone whose nickname was Duca?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you find out who this person was and which unit he belonged to or which body he was a part of?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I heard that he was a Serb. As for his full name, I never found out what it was, and I never tried to find out what it was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you at any point in time find out that he was sentenced to 31 years in prison in a court in Bosnia-Herzegovina?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I didn't hear about that. And I didn't read about it in the media either.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You mentioned someone whose nickname is Cupo. Do you remember that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you at any point in time discover the name of that person?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I didn't find out anything else about him, apart from the fact that he had a twin brother. But I never found out what his full name was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you hear that Cupo who had a twin brother stood trial before the ICTY?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, as I have said. And I didn't know his first and last name.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You also mentioned someone whose nickname was Kajin. So my question is the same: Did you ever find out who this person was. Kajin.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I didn't.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You couldn't say whether they were members of the military or of the police force; isn't that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I couldn't say. I did see Kajin, but as to whether he was a policeman or not, or something else, I couldn't say.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever hear the name of Dusko Sikirica.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I have heard that name.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever know whether he was in Keraterm or around Keraterm and whether he was performing any duties in Keraterm at the time that you were there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: There was nothing I could say about that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You couldn't tell the Prosecution when directly asked about it whether you could recognise any of the people who fired on the detainees in room on that fatal night?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I never those people and I never saw them before, and I never saw them afterwards either.

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Microphone, please.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'd like us to have a look at part of your statement, it's the proffer the testimony.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: And could we see the 65 ter document, 28360 in the e-court system, please. And let's have a look at page in the B/C/S version.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: This is Exhibit P158, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: It's number 63.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Paragraph 63. And have a look at this part of your statement, please. You say the following. At one point in time, you saw the door being opened and you saw people from inside coming out. Can you see that part of your statement?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I can.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At that point in time you were in room number 2.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The opening from which you could see this, was it a window or was it some other kind of opening?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It wasn't a window. It was the door through which we entered room number and through which we exited room number 2.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You said that the door to the room opened. Can you tell us specifically what you saw? How was it that the door came to be opened?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, I've already said. The first time that you could hear moans and shouts for air, that they were asking, Shoot. They were -- I could hear that they were banging on the door asking for the door to be opened. I don't know if it was locked or not. Most probably they broke through the door to get some air, and when they broke through the door, then the Serb soldiers started shooting at them as if they were trying to escape, because they had knocked down the door after the soldiers had warned them, Stop running. We're going to shoot.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And before the shooting started, did you see how many people, how many inmates managed to leave facility 3? Did you keep looking?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The question is not clear to me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right. I'm sorry. I will rephrase it then. Did you see - and if you did see - in your estimate how many people from facility left that room before the shooting started?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When you say "people," do you mean the prisoners? What sort of people?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yes. Prisoners, inmates, people who had been brought in?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You mean if they left -- if they exited before the shooting started?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yes, that's right?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I didn't see any of them come outside. No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In your statement, I think you said something slightly different. Can you look at paragraph 63, please. You said that you saw how people were coming out and that some of them started running in different directions, and now you say that did you not see anybody come outside before the shooting. What is correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, you asked me if anybody came out before the shooting. Nobody came out before the shooting. The people started to go out after they broke through the door. After the poisons were lobbed inside, they couldn't get out. Then they broke through the door. They had nowhere else to go. But by that time, they had already started shooting at them. They couldn't all run in one direction.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The young man whom you mentioned in your statement and who survived the tragic incident told you in more detail what happened; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did this young man faint inside facility number 3?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And were you in a position to see if how many other people stayed in the facility, according to information that you might have received?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, there were two other people with him. Although I spoke with him, I didn't know him before, but his sister was married to a neighbour of mine.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And these two men, did they also survive this tragic incident?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were unhurt. They were in good condition, in a good state of health. But I don't know what happened to them later.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, I think you asked for 40 minutes before the break, which means that you would have, not deducing any time for the late start, that you would have another five to seven minutes. And in view of the relevance, the level of relevance of some of the earlier questions, the Chamber would like to keep you to that time estimate.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Thank you. I'm going to stick to the time, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, at one point in time, in late July 1992, you were transferred to Trnopolje with another group of prisoners. I'm asking you this because I would like to ask you whether you know that after you left Keraterm was dismantled as a collection centre?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know. I didn't have any information as to whether anybody stayed in those rooms. When we left, we were called out by name. Some went to Omarska, some went to Trnopolje, so I really couldn't see anymore if anybody stayed behind or not. I actually boarded a bus that was going to Trnopolje. I don't know anything else.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you stayed in Trnopolje for about 20 days.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Until the 21st of August more precisely.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did your wife and children manage to leave Prijedor?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. My wife and the children did leave, but not from Prijedor but from Trnopolje in freight railway cars that would transport cattle before that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did she manage to leave before you to the territory under the control of the Army of Bosnia and Herzegovina?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, she did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You reached the area of Travnik via Vlasic. Am I correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And when you arrived, were you militarily engaged by Bosnia and Herzegovina?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When I came to Travnik, I was very ill. I couldn't walk. I couldn't stand on my feet, on my legs. I was exhausted, undernourished. I sought medical help which was not really readily available in Travnik. They were encircled. They couldn't provide anything like that, so I had to ask for help outside of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and I was not mobilised anywhere or -- nor did I wear a military uniform, as they say.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did the military authorities help you? Did you leave Bosnia and Herzegovina or did you remain in Bosnia and Herzegovina for some time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they heeded my request. I asked to go for medical treatment in Croatia and that's where I was transferred, to Croatia for medical treatment.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And were you militarily engaged in the territory of Croatia until the end of the war at any point in time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I spent a short time in Croatia, perhaps two weeks or so, and then later, I went to Slovenia. My brother came to get me, and then my wife came to Slovenia to join me, and then I left farther away, together with her.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you. And now I'm going to finish by --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic, one of the previous answers of the witness was: "And I was not mobilised anywhere or -- nor did I wear a military uniform, as they say." That means not engaged in any army activities. Why ask that twice? There's no need to do that. Please put your last questions to the witness.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: Your Honour, that question referred to the answer by the witness that he went to Croatia during the war, so I just wanted to deal with that question in line with the suggestions that I had.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. The witness said "anywhere." Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: I have no further questions, Your Honours. Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Stojanovic. Mr. Traldi, any need to re-examine the witness?

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Just very briefly, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And how much time would you need? Because I'll first check with my colleagues whether we have any additional questions.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I would have one or two questions for the witness. And how much time would you need for re-examination?

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: I only have two questions, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Two questions only. Yes. Questioned by the Court:

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Then, Mr. Taci, I have two questions for you. You repeatedly said that you had no knowledge after you had returned to your place. Now, in the proffer of testimony I read the following: "He heard some announcements on Radio Prijedor saying that the population in Kozarac should surrender, that the Serbs were a peaceful people, that they should live together, and that the power should be turned over to the Serbs." That line suggests that you were able to listen to the radio. Because, earlier, when asked about rendering any arms, you said, Well, we had no contact whatsoever, we couldn't know. Here in your proffer of evidence you say that you were listening to Prijedor Radio. Could you explain.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour. When I said that I listened to the radio, I said that the children that were going to school in Prijedor, they would go there. The phones were working. There was electricity when I arrived from Croatia. However, little by little everything was shutting down. Information, local transport, the schools, the electricity, the water. Everything was shut down. After that, we didn't have any more information or radio or anything like that. We didn't get any information or communication with Prijedor or from anybody else.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: So you say it changed over time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: My next question - and also my last question - is the following. You say you observed from room number what happened outside not through a window but through the door through which you entered and left. Does that mean that the door in room was ajar, that you -- it was slightly open? It was not locked?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The door was not locked. Afterwards, they placed a kind of iron fencing there in place of a door. But there was no door there, so I could get near that opening and observe what was going on.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. You say there was no door. It was just an opening where a door was supposed to be. Is that how I have to understand your testimony?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. There had been a door there before. Then they took down that original door. And then they welded some bars there so that we couldn't go out at night. It was locked. But we could get some air through that door.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And you saw the events through that -- those bars, if I -- is that how I have to understand your answer?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And room was not treated in a similar way. There still was a door, if -- did I understand you correctly?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Room did have a door. I don't remember the colour or anything like that now. And that room was much smaller than room number 2.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you for those answers. Mr. Traldi, if it's a matter of a couple of minutes, then we'll ... and then we take a break after that.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, at temporary transcript page 30, you told Mr. Stojanovic that "... only Muslim police remained ..." in the Kozarac police force. Could you tell the Trial Chamber at about what time did the Kozarac police become all Muslim?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I couldn't tell you the exact time because I didn't have any contacts with the policemen. I didn't have anything in common with them. I don't know how many of them there were. In any case, it was in my estimate that those who remained were Muslim police officers. Then also some of them arrived from Prijedor because none of the Muslim policemen could remain in Prijedor, or in Kozarac. So they all came to Kozarac.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you say "those who remained," sir, do you mean those who remained as of May 1992, as of the middle of May, as of June? Can you estimate the time for us?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I really couldn't tell you exactly, but it was when the children stopped going to school, when the Serbian forces captured Prijedor, and then they tried to get the people in Kozarac to surrender, to put up that flag, and I think that already by that time, there were no other -- there were no members from other ethnic groups in the police force anymore.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, at pages 42 and 43 of today's temporary transcript, Mr. Stojanovic asked you about Duca, Cupo, and Kajin. At paragraph of your statement, you say Kajin wore a camouflage uniform. Did you ever see Duca or Cupo wearing uniforms?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I saw Cupo wearing the shirt from the uniform, but I did not see Duca in a military uniform, no. Meaning that he was wearing civilian clothing.

sp.speaker: MR. TRALDI:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour. That completes my re-examination.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Traldi. I see, Mr. Stojanovic, that the questions by the Bench and in re-examination have triggered no need for further questions. Mr. Taci, this concludes, then, your evidence in this case. I'd like to thank you very much for coming to The Hague and for answering the questions that were put to you, put to you by the parties and by the Bench, and I wish you a safe return home again. You may follow the usher.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We will take a break, and we resume at 10 minutes past 1.00. --- Recess taken at 12.41 p.m. --- On resuming at 1.12 p.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Before I invite the Prosecution to call its next witness, which will be taken by whom?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Your Honours. Camille Bibles will --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Ms. Bibles, so you will take the witness. I think the witness could already be escorted close to the courtroom, I would say. Meanwhile, we'll deal with another matter; that is, the administrative hearings as suggested by the Prosecution. Mr. Lukic, last Friday you said, I think, that you are not objecting but I left it open whether you wanted to make any further submissions. Now I do not know whether you wish to do so or not, or that you say, Well, we just do not object.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: On what, Your Honour? [Overlapping speakers]
