sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Administrative hearings on witness scheduling.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: We don't object. The only thing we wanted to raise right now, Your Honour, is that maybe we will not be able to tell Your Honours and the Prosecution the exact amount of time we need for the cross-examination at that moment since we would learn only then who would come.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. I see that point. And I don't think that that in itself is objecting against following the suggestion.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: No, Your Honour. And any information, however imprecise, is better than what we're doing now, which is simply making decisions based on no information.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Then the Chamber has no objection to discussing upcoming scheduling issues, as suggested by the Prosecution, but only so long as it does not interfere with finishing the testimony of witnesses. We would not like to have the witness stay for a weekend because we so urgently had to discuss the scheduling issues. And the Chamber expects the Prosecution therefore to proactively to raise any scheduling matters at an appropriate time, and certainly the end of a cyclus would certainly be one of those moments.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: Your Honour, if I could make a suggestion. If before Friday Mr. Lukic were able to fill in the estimates for the first four weeks when we return, the hearing could actually be quite brief, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Mr. Lukic, you're invited to look at that.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour. We'll do our best.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Could the witness be escorted into the courtroom.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honour, just briefly, there is an issue to raise with the Trial Chamber prior to the witness's actual arrival.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, I would like to address the attention that this Trial Chamber has brought to this next witness's testimony, and I believe it was placed on the record on the 9th of July of this year. Your Honour, we do intend to rely very heavily on adjudicated facts 460, 462 to 465, 468 to 476 with respect to Manjaca in leading this witness's testimony. We will also rely heavily on adjudicated facts 1141 through 1144 and 1146 with respect to it the takeover the Sanski Most. As well, to some degree, the adjudicated facts in 1165 to 1169, and certainly with respect to 1190 and 1192. However, as the Trial Chamber has alluded, as part of our prosecutorial judgement, we do make an evaluation of each witness and their evidence. Now, in this --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: In the case of this particular witness, after reviewing the evidence and in consultation with Mr. Groome, we have determined that there is some evidence that he has that we would lead in full. So unless there's a -- there are additional concerns from the Trial Chamber, then we can go ahead and bring in Mr. Begic.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. When I make this observation, and I've done that several times, if you say these are the adjudicated facts, we'd like to know, but nevertheless it remains the responsibility of the Prosecution to clearly define for itself what the matters are for which no evidence needs to be led, because the Chamber doesn't take responsibility for that. The Chamber, at the very end, will just look at what was proven and, as far as adjudicated facts is concerned, apart from challenges, whether -- if you rely on the adjudicated fact it could not beyond what the adjudicated facts tell us. If that is clear, then if there's no other matter, the witness could be escorted into the courtroom. Or is there?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: No, that's it, Your Honour. Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Thank you, Ms. Bibles.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Begic, I take it. Before you give evidence, the Rules require that you make a solemn declaration. I invite you to make that declaration, of which the text will now be handed out to you by the usher.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you. I solemnly declare that I will speak the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Begic. Pleas be seated.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Begic, you will first be examined by Ms. Bibles. Ms. Bibles is counsel for the Prosecution. You find her to your right. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Good afternoon, Mr. Begic. Could you introduce yourself with your full name and your age, please.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Good afternoon. My name is Rajif Begic. I was born on 23rd September 1967. So I'm 45.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you also have a nickname?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. They call me Raho.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you tell us which village and municipality in which you were born?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I was born and grew up in the village of Plevci, Sanski Most municipality.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you briefly describe us the hamlet or the villages that are in the area of Sanski Most where you lived?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Around Sanski Most, to the right of the river Sana, there was Kljevci village, which is a large village with several hamlets in it; such as Begici, Kenjari, Cosici, Stojnovci, and just after Kljevci came Hrustovo village, Vrhpolje, Tomina river, Caplivo [phoen]

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: And Your Honours, if we could bring 65 ter 08755 to our screens.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Have you had an opportunity to review a map with the villages and their ethnic composition in 1992 from Sanski Most?

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Sorry Madam Bibles, what's the 65 ter number?

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
Q.
sp.p: Looking at the map that is on the screen in front of you, do you recognise this map?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. That's Sanski Most municipality.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Does it fairly and accurately depict the villages of Sanski Most as they existed in 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And directing your attention to the lower right-hand portion of the map, do you see the area in which you lived?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Villages Vrhpolje, Hrustovo, Begici, Kenjari. That's the area where I lived, in the lower right corner.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: The Prosecution tenders 65 ter 08755.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Madam Registrar.

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: No objection.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 08755 becomes Exhibit P162, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: P162 is admitted into evidence.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
Q.
sp.p: Could you describe for us in the time period before the conflict in Bosnia what the relationships were like between Muslims and Serbs in your area?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. In the village of Kljevci and with other villages around Kljevci, interpersonal relations were very good. We grew up in villages with a mixed population. We went to school together. We socialised among ethnic communities, and before the war there had been no incidents on a nationalist grounds.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What is the ethnicity of your godparents?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They are Serbs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And could you tell us who they are?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Vid Krlic and Andza Krlic. Our neighbours from Begici village.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you have a close relationship with them up through 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: You could say so. We were close. We shared some agricultural machinery. We owned them jointly. We were friends. They were my godparents, my godmother -- my godmother cut my hair when I was born, and according to our customs, thus, she same my godmother.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'd like to turn your attention to May of 1992.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: And Your Honours, I am going to be limiting my questions in this regard in reliance on adjudicated facts 1141 to 1144.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In May of 1992, did you surrender any weapons?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My neighbours from Begici village handed over some weapons. I didn't have any.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were you able to hear the radio broadcasts directing Muslims to surrender weapons?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Several days before the 25th of May, the local radio broadcast that local villages, including Kljevci, should hand over any weapons they had at the closest Serb check-point.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: During any time in 1992, were you involved in any actions to defend your village or any other territory?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. There were no such actions.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: We're aware that your village was first attack in May of 1992. Can you tell us what date that was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was the 25th of May.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know which military unit controlled the area in which you lived?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was a part of the 6th Krajina Brigade that was based in the primary school, the four-year school, in Kljevci.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who the commander of that unit was in -- in May of 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. The commander of that unit was Mile Mijatovic, and he once visited us at the hamlet. He introduced himself, so we knew who commanded that unit.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know approximately what date he came to your village?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I can't tell you the exact date, but it was a couple of days before the 25th. Perhaps the 23rd or the 21st.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you tell us how he introduced himself to you and your family?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. One day, accompanied by a soldier, both of them armed, we -- they came to our house with the intention of meeting all the residents of that village. He said where he hailed from, whose son he was, and we knew that, although he wasn't living in Kljevci by that time. We knew his father. And that conversation over coffee was not long. He told us a couple of things about the situation, and then he left.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he say what army he was a commander in?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. He said he had a unit from the 6th Krajina Brigade that was based at the school, which we had not known, and he said he was in charge of that part of Kljevci.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he say if he was with the JNA or the VRS or what military organisation?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He did not tell us exactly the name of his unit. He just said it was the 6th Krajina Brigade. I did not hear him mention the VRS or the JNA.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who the komandant for the 6th Krajina Brigade was in 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. The commander of the 6th Krajina Brigade was Branko Basara.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And how is it that you know that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, after doing my military service, I was, myself, part of the reserve force of the 6th Krajina Brigade. We all knew that, as far as the reserve force is concerned, our area was covered by the 6th Krajina Brigade. Just before the events, a month or two before, Branko Basara attended a meeting in Tomina, where he met locals from the surrounding villages, where he introduced himself. He was wearing a uniform. And the issue came up of where to put up some units and where to deploy some tanks and howitzers in the area, so that's when I met him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And I don't believe that I've asked you this yet, but what is your ethnicity?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I'm a Muslim, a Bosniak.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the end of May 1992, did you come to know a soldier whose last name was Palija?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I met a soldier by the name of Jadranko Palija.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was your understanding as to where he came from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I did not know that soldier, Jadranko Palija before. Once, driving my tractor by a Serb check-point, I was stopped by my Serb neighbours, and Jadranko Palija was among them. They talked to me briefly while he searched the tractor checking whether I had any weapons in there, and I heard someone address him as Jadranko. At that time I did not know his last name, Palija.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did you later come to understand where he had come from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I think it was already on the next day when my godmother Andza, passing by, stopped at our house for coffee and he said that a soldier was visiting her house by the name of Jadranko Palija and that perhaps he had a thing for her daughter. So that's the first time I heard his last name.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is that how you learned where he came from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. When she was talking about him, she stressed that he lived in Croatia, and as the war was moving to Bosnia, he fled to Bosnia and he was assigned to be in that locality.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And by that locality, was that your area?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I mean that locality. More precisely, that first check-point that was put up next to Begici village. He was assigned to man that check-point.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: May I interrupt you for a moment for the clarity of the record. You told us about the check-point where you were stopped with your tractor and somebody addressed this man we were -- you were talking about as Jadranko without mentioning his family name. Is that correct?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes, that's correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: And then, in that case, on page 62, line 17, the second word should be deleted or redacted. Only Jadranko was mentioned. You learned his last name only later. Is that correct.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: That's correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: For the completeness of the record, I notice that on the one screen the numbering of the lines is slightly different from the other one, but I think it is clear it is the words before it says "at that time I did not know his last name, Palija." Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The -- can you describe for us what the soldier, Palija's attitude towards the Muslims in the area was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, I did not see that soldier again after those days. That was my first meeting with him, and then the next time I saw him it was already 31st of May, so I don't know if he had had any contacts in the meantime with my neighbours.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: During the time-period from the 25th of May to the 31st of May, can you describe what life was like for you and your family?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. After this first incursion of soldiers into our hamlet, until the 31st, we lived in fear. On the 25th, when they entered the hamlet, they mistreated and beat people. And in the days that followed, fear reigned, and we were completely at a loss what to expect.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where were you when your village was attacked on the 25th of May of 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: On the 25th, when the troops were coming into our hamlet, I was outside my house with my brother. When they came by, it was in fact a young man who was running ahead of them, saying, The army is coming. My junior -- my younger brother, Munib Begic, and I ran to the river to hide there, not far from the house.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were you able to see or hear what was going on with your village?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We were not able to see, but we could hear everything. Perhaps not every word, but we could clearly hear what was going on around our houses.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you describe just briefly what it was that you were able to hear from the river?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. We could hear our old aunt trying to defend her old husband, Huso, who was 75. And next to them we could hear small children crying. We could hear soldiers shouting, Get into the garage. We're going to kill you now. There were many voices at the same time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long did the attack last?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not long. Not longer than an hour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'm now directing your attention to the 31st of May of 1992. I'd like you to think about the soldiers that entered your village on that date. Were there soldiers that you did not know?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: On that day, the 31st of May, I recognised some of the soldiers whom I had known from before, from the town and school, but most of them were not familiar.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you describe for us whether you knew the soldier who ordered the separation of women and children from the men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I did not know that soldier. All I could see was that he was in command of that unit that was in Begici on that day.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was there any fighting or resistance from the Muslims in the community?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you describe what happened to the men in your community as the separations occurred?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. When the locals from Dizdarevici and Donji Begici were brought to us, I lived in Gornji Begici, the men who were found in the basement of Ekrem Begic were lined up outside the house. As we were coming to Gornji Begici, it was ordered already that women and children should go to one side, whereas the men should form a column to join the men who had already been lined up.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did the men do as they were told?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Yes, we did as we were told. We had to line up.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And can you describe how the column was organised, the column of men?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: After separating the women and children, and even one underaged boy managed to join the group of women and children with his mother, they lined us up in a column two by two and told us to go towards Vinogradi.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many armed soldiers escorted your group of men away?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Our column that was going towards Vrhpolje was escorted by many armed soldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know who the leader of that group of soldiers was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The one who was in charge of escorting the column was Jadranko Palija.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At that time did you know any of the other soldiers that he was commanding?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I recognised some of the young men who were from Sanski Most, from the town.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you describe for us if you knew where you were going?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. While we were still standing in Begici, the officer who was in charge of those soldiers on that day said the soldiers would escort us to the bridge over the Sana river where buses were waiting for us.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Approximately how far did you -- would you go from Begici to the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: At least kilometre.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you describe for us the ages in your group, the ages of the Muslim men? Just roughly. The youngest and the oldest.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. The youngest in the group was called Enes Dizdarevic, and at the time he was between 15 and 16 years old. Edin Begic, my youngest brother, had been put aside with his mother because he seemed younger but he was the same age. The oldest one was Sacir Begic who was over 70 years old, and there was Miralem Celic [as interpreted]
, who was perhaps a year or two younger.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: As your group walked towards the bridge, did you go by some other soldiers?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Not far from the Begici hamlet that we were moving away from, we came across a group of soldiers who were resting by the road that we were travelling down.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And how did they react to your group?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Jadranko stopped our group there, and then these soldiers, about 30 of them, insulted us, cursed us. Someone even said that we should be killed there on the spot. But they did not beat us on that occasion.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And how long did you stay in that location?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not long. A few minutes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And which direction did you go from there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: After that, Jadranko Palija ordered the column to move on in the same direction, towards Vinogradine about 100 metres away from that road.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were you able to move at the pace that you wanted to -- to move, or you and the group?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. We were ordered to maintain a steady pace, although we had to bring these old people along with us too. Because at one point in time, Jadranko Palija said that if someone shooted at the column from the surrounding villages, they would all kill us. And that is why it was necessary for us to move rapidly. Some were not able to keep up and we therefore had to help them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right. Who had the most trouble keeping up?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Sacir Begic and Miralem Ceric found it most difficult. Miralem, after about 100 metres, had pain and felt pain in the heart and his son tried to take care of him. We had to carry Sacir Begic. Irfan and myself grabbed him by the arms and helped him, while the other people in the column were able to move ahead on their own.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: While you were moving towards the bridge in this column, could you describe for us what was happening in the area?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. As we approached the Hrustovac [as interpreted]

station where there were a number of houses, we noticed that all the houses were on fire. You could see a weapon firing. You could see soldiers sitting by the road. Some were cursing. Others drinking. Some were stealing cars or items from cars. It was ugly. An ugly scene.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How many smaller bridges did you cross before getting to Vrhpolje bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, as we were approaching Hrustovac station there was a small bridge over the Glibaja river, that we then had to cross a bridge over the Sanica river. That was in Hrustovo station. And then we headed onto this other bridge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In that area that you've just described --

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: Near Vrhpolje, interpreter's correction. A bridge near Vrhpolje.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: After crossing that area, could you describe for us how Miralem Ceric was doing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, at that point in time, when we arrived at Hrustovac station we could see that Miralem Ceric was out of breath, and he was breathing with difficulty and it would have been good for him to have a break. He was breathing with difficulty and moving with difficulty, although his son Enes was helping him to -- to walk.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you tell the Judges what, if anything, Palija did as a result of his difficulties?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. At one point in time when we were crossing the -- a bridge over the Sanica river, right by the bridge on the left-hand side there was a slaughter-house, an abandoned slaughter-house. At that point in time, as we were passing by that slaughter-house, Jadranko took Miralem Ceric and his son Enes aside. In fact, he took them into that old slaughter-house. When the three of them entered the slaughter-house, I saw Jadranko Palija taking out his pistol and following them inside, in fact. I then heard a shot, and I saw Jadranko Palija coming out of the slaughter-house and putting the pistol back into its holster. He then joined the column which hadn't stopped advancing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you ever see either of these two men again?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I didn't.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Palija take anyone else from the column after that?

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: Before you move to that question. May I ask you to clarify. Sorry. You said you heard a shot. One shot or more shots?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: As I said, at that point in time, all the houses in the vicinity of the bridge were on fire and the bricks were actually cracking. I heard a shot which was a pistol shot. I'm sure that I heard one shot. I didn't hear any other shots. Perhaps because of the noise being produced by the houses that were on fire and by the bricks that were cracking. But I am certain that I heard one shot being fired.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: Thank you for that.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
Q.
sp.p: Did Palija take anyone else from your column after that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. The column continued towards the Vrhpolje bridge and then we had to get to the main road that was about 250 metres from that location. And at the exit that leads to the main road, Jadranko took Ismet Kurbegovic out of the column. He took him to the other side of the road and killed him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did he -- did Palija say anything to Ismet before he killed him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Jadranko took him aside. He pointed his gun at him, and he said, For the last time, I'm asking you, where is your sniper? Ismet said he did not have a sniper rifle of any kind, and this man then shot him.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you actually see the shot?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Sorry, Madam Bibles. The shot or the shooting?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: I'm sorry. I will rephrase that to the shooting.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you see the shooting?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He killed him with one shot from the gun.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Was this the same pistol that you saw him holster a few minutes before?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, it was the same one.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did Palija come back to your group at that point?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. This all happened quite quickly. The column hadn't really moved very far, and you could see him walking -- walking by with the column.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what happened to Ismet's body?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: His body remained lying by the road, by a stop sign. His body remained lying there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you came within 10 metres of the Vrhpolje bridge, could you see who was on the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. From a certain distance you could see that there were a lot of soldiers on the bridge. It wasn't really possible to see them clearly until we had actually reached the bridge. Having reached the bridge, I could recognise some of those soldiers.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Were there buses on the bridge when you could first see it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I didn't see any.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: As you got very close to the bridge, did any vehicles come alongside your group?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. At one point in time, just before we reached the bridge, a military van, a small military van, arrived from the direction of Kljuc. There was one driver in it. Though the van was advancing at the same speed as the column, and then the driver in the van told Jadranko Palija to get in and sit down to his right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you describe what happened after he got in the vehicle?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: After Jadranko Palija got into the van, the column continued advancing on the left-hand side, and at that point in time Irfan Begic and myself were still helping Sacir Begic to walk. Elmedin Begic instinctively grabbed Sacir Begic to help him move, and then Jadranko Palija who was sitting in the van called out to Irfan Begic and told him to move in front of the van and to go to the other side, the side on which he was sitting. When Irfan Begic crossed over to the other side of the road in front of the van, I had a look to the right, to my side, and I saw that Jadranko Palija didn't say anything, but when Irfan arrived by the window, he shot him from his pistol.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At that point, what were you thinking?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, we were terrified by what we had seen. Appalled by it. We had to go to the bridge. We had to continue to the bridge.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, could exhibit 65 ter 06367 be brought to our screens.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you recognise what is depicted in this photograph?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. The photograph depicts the Vrhpolje bridge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is this the same bridge that was there on the 31st of May of 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, it's the same bridge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Is it -- and could you tell us the name of the river that we see running under the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that is the river Sana.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At -- I'm going to ask you to make some markings on this photograph but not just yet, and I would ask for the colour red to be used with the pen. Do you know which direction this river flows?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. From left to right. If you look at the photograph, it's from left to right.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'm going to ask that you take the pen and draw a small -- I'm sorry, just a moment. I'm going to ask that you draw a small arrow on the river indicating which direction of river flows, please.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: [Marks]

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Could the usher otherwise assist the witness in using the eraser as well.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Does the river flow from the left on the picture to the right. Is that -- is it possible to --

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes. [Marks]

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
Q.
sp.p: Could you --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. Bibles, before we continue, 65 ter 06367 is described on our list as photo of the Vrhpolje bridge annotated by the witness, but are there any previous annotations or is it?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honour, there do not appear to be any annotations.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: So we will need to correct that description of the photograph.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Once it is admitted, if you tender it, then, of course, there are annotations. So perhaps you have anticipated on what might happen in court. But I was just wondering whether I missed something. But let's proceed. I've heard your answer.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
Q.
sp.p: Do you see the road that you entered the bridge from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you please take the pen and mark a number on the road that will show us the direction that you came from?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: [Marks]

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. Bibles, it's -- apart from you do not come from a direction but you come from a place and then move in a certain direction.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do I understand that, looking at this picture, you came to the bridge from the left on the road, as we see it, moving to the right and thus arriving at the bridge?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes, correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed, Ms. Bibles.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
Q.
sp.p: And I'll have you go ahead and just put the pen down for a moment.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
Q.
sp.p: As your column came onto the bridge, could you tell us what happened?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. As we approached the bridge, we were going down the left side of the road. And when we reached the bridge, we were ordered to go to the right part of the fence on the bridge and to line up in a column, one by one, in the middle of the bridge at that point.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Would this have been on the up-river side of the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, the right side of the bridge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: As you -- after you lined up, what did they have you do next?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: After we had lined up, we were ordered to take our shoes off and our clothes. Not all of our clothes, but most of them. And that's what we did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right. And could you describe for us, as you did that, what the soldiers were doing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. As soon as we started approaching the bridge, they started cursing and maltreating us. And then when all the people had taken their clothes off, one or two soldiers searched the people who were lined up there. They asked us whether we had any money on us or any weapons, and they asked us to display what we had, if we had anything, and then they started beating certain people, certain individuals, on the bridge.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When you finished -- which clothing did you take off?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I took off my trousers, my shoes, some remained in their trousers. Some didn't take their shoes off. Well, in fact, everyone took their shoes off. But, on the whole, there were a lot of clothes piled up on the bridge. Some would remain wearing two T-shirts, two shirts. They didn't order us to take everything off.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what were you still wearing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I had a short white T-shirt.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: As the beatings were happening, did someone start to talk about going off the bridge?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you describe for us what happened after the beatings started?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. They were beating Hakija Begic, Mile Begic at the time. They were also beating Fuad Begic. And then at one point in time they started beating everyone. So, on the whole, everyone was beaten.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they say anything to you as to what was going to happen to you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. While this beating and cursing and -- was going on, while they were insulting us, Kaurin, Nenad, Nenad Kaurin, said aloud that they had to kill 70 Muslims on that day because seven Serbian soldiers had been killed during that period in that area.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What were you thinking at that point in time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We were frightened. We had been beaten up. It was cold. We were no longer thinking about buses arriving there. We were just waiting to see what the fate of the group would be. We'd been abandoned to our fate.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: All right.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, having just glanced at the time, I'm wondering if this would be a point at which we should take a break for the day.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, if you think this is a suitable moment. I take it, then, that the next line of questions would take more than the two or three minutes we have left.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. Bibles, do you intend to have more markings? Because there's a bit of a problem if we adjourn for the day, that we can't keep it as it is, the photograph of the bridge.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour, I would tender exhibit 65 ter 06367.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Which is now a photograph of Vrhpolje bridge marked by the witnesses, isn't it. Madam Registrar, the number would be.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 06367 as marked by the witness in court becomes Exhibit P163, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Registrar. And P163 is admitted into evidence. Mr. Begic, we'd like to see you back tomorrow morning at 9.30. But before you leave, I'd like to instruct you that should not speak with anyone or communicate in any other way with whomever about your testimony, whether that is your testimony as you have given it today or whether that is testimony still to be given tomorrow. Is that clear to you?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes, that's clear.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please follow the usher.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We adjourn for the day, and we resume tomorrow, Tuesday, the 4th of September, at 9.30 in the morning, in this same courtroom, I.
sp.stage: --- Whereupon the hearing adjourned at 2.15 p.m., to be resumed on Tuesday, the 4th day of September, 2012, at 9.30 a.m.
